Greetings,

Somehow, in my short time being alive, I believe we are entering into a second Zeitgeist‚Äîa cultural shift as seismic as the first Zeitgeist I experienced on the morning of September 11th, 2001.

Then, we transitioned rapidly into an era of obedience by design. At first, it was about safety, about resilience. However‚Ä¶what followed‚Äîsurveillance, censorship, militarized borders, the erosion of civic trust‚Äîwas something far deeper, and far more permanent.

I was born in 1988. Since then, I have known nothing but a world in crisis. My nation, that I love so deeply, perpetually at war. Let us recount the entire reckoning:

  • 1989 ‚Äì Operation Just Cause in Panama
  • 1990‚Äì1991 ‚Äì Gulf War
  • 1992‚Äì1995 ‚Äì Operation Restore Hope in Somalia
  • 1994 ‚Äì Operation Uphold Democracy in Haiti
  • 1999 ‚Äì Kosovo bombings via NATO, split congressional vote
  • 2001‚Äì2021 ‚Äì Afghanistan War under open-ended AUMF ‚Äî my stepbrother, friends, and family deployed, some to not return (thankfully, my brother did, but forever broken)
  • 2003‚Äì2011 ‚Äì Iraq War, again without formal declaration
  • 2011 ‚Äì Operation Odyssey Dawn in Libya, executive-led
  • 2014‚ÄìPresent ‚Äì Ongoing Syria airstrikes, claimed under outdated AUMFs
  • 2015‚ÄìPresent ‚Äì Support for Saudi-led war in Yemen, despite humanitarian catastrophe
  • 2010s‚ÄìPresent ‚Äì AFRICOM operations, drone strikes across the continent, without public awareness
  • 2022‚ÄìPresent ‚Äì Billions in military aid and support for Ukraine

These are only the public operations we can actually document (or put online for the general population). Since WWII, the U.S. has conducted over 100 military operations globally, the vast majority of them undeclared or unauthorized by Congress‚Äîin fact, some would contend most if not all were unconstitutional by design.

No draft. No debate. No accountability. Yet still‚Äîwe remain silent‚Äîor, at least, we remain unheard.

But the most insidious war today?

Is the one no one names:

The war on information.
The war on attention.
The war on memory.
The war of and by AI.

Our Journey

Timeline data is maintained in a Google Sheet that can be collaboratively edited. Make sure to publish the spreadsheet to the web for the timeline to work.

Our Journey

Operation Just Cause (Panama)

1989

The U.S. invaded Panama to depose Manuel Noriega. Marked the beginning of Netu's birth-era conflict list.

Gulf War

1990 ‚Äî 1991

Operation Desert Storm. U.S.-led coalition liberated Kuwait from Iraq. Signaled U.S. military dominance post-Cold War.

Operation Restore Hope (Somalia)

1992 ‚Äî 1995

U.S. humanitarian mission turned into combat. Notoriously escalated with the 'Black Hawk Down' incident.

Operation Uphold Democracy (Haiti)

1994

U.S. intervened to restore democratically elected President Aristide following a coup.

Kosovo Bombings via NATO

1999

U.S. participated in NATO airstrikes against Yugoslavia over Kosovo. Highly controversial; Congress was split.

Afghanistan War

2001 ‚Äî 2021

Launched post-9/11 under AUMF. Longest U.S. war. Personal toll: Netu's stepbrother returned broken.

Iraq War

2003 ‚Äî 2011

Invasion justified by WMD claims. No formal declaration. Left a power vacuum, seeded extremism.

AFRICOM Drone Strikes & Raids (Ongoing)

2010 ‚Äî Present

Covert drone operations across Africa. Rarely discussed in public. Bypassed most oversight.

Operation Odyssey Dawn (Libya)

2011

U.S. joined NATO airstrikes to enforce a no-fly zone during Libyan Civil War. Bypassed Congress.

Syria Airstrikes (Ongoing)

2014 ‚Äî Present

Airstrikes against ISIS and others, claimed under post-9/11 AUMF. Yet ISIS did not exist in 2001.

Support for Saudi-led War in Yemen

2015 ‚Äî Present

U.S. provided weapons, intelligence, and refueling to coalition. Caused massive humanitarian crisis.

Support for Ukraine (Ongoing)

2022 ‚Äî Present

Massive U.S. aid to Ukraine following Russian invasion. Billions in arms, logistics, and intelligence.

Timeline data is maintained in a Google Sheet that can be collaboratively edited.

We are building ever-more-powerful AI systems atop a broken and corrupted substrate:

  • Information ecosystems warped by profit ‚Äî where surveillance masquerades as convenience. Mark Zuckerberg didn‚Äôt just build a social network‚Äîhe studied Mandarin, courted autocracy, and developed an entire platform tailored to feed information directly to the Chinese Communist Party. This wasn‚Äôt accidental; it was strategic. If our leading technocrats bend the knee so quickly, so willingly‚Äîwhat hope do we have of regulating the next generation of cognitive empires?
  • Civic platforms that ignore the invisible ‚Äî the destitute, the undocumented, the digitally disconnected. It no longer matters your race, creed, or politics‚Äîif you‚Äôre not monetizable, if you‚Äôre not loud in the right algorithmic register, then you simply do not exist. The quiet soup kitchen. The grandmother-led food pantry. The local healer without a Twitter account. Gone.
  • Interfaces that confuse engagement with meaning ‚Äî optimized for consumption, not connection. ‚ÄúShop here.‚Äù ‚ÄúBuy more.‚Äù ‚ÄúSwipe now.‚Äù Designed to keep you spending just enough to stay numb, but never enough to reach sufficiency. They are not neutral UX flows‚Äîthey are psychological casinos engineered to erode sovereignty.

If we do not rebuild our epistemic engines‚Äîthose that help people know, decide, and act together‚Äîwe won‚Äôt just lose truth.

We will lose the capacity for collective coherence. We will have no ontological metanarrative whatsoever.

Therefore, I‚Äôve spent my career building or chasing counter-systems.

Tools that turn complexity into clarity. Chaos into coordination. Automation into alignment with human dignity.

I‚Äôve built or had the esteemed privilege of working at building:

  • Unusual Whales ‚Äî The true democratization of stock market information; the counter to the Bloomberg terminal
  • FLOW / KOS / Principus ‚Äî A testable governance and reasoning layer for intelligent agents navigating contradiction, shifting trust, and epistemic thresholds
  • Civic Atlas ‚Äî A decentralized civic discovery engine designed to map hidden local opportunity and lift the quiet voices ignored by SEO and adtech
  • Markets News & CardByMe ‚Äî LLM-powered platforms fighting financial disinformation and reviving human presence through postal tech

All rooted in the belief that technology must restore balance.
Not just ease burdens‚Äîbut return sovereignty, enhance agency, and reweave meaning.

We do not need more charters.
We need counter-infrastructure.

  • Systems that flag contradiction, not smooth it over
  • Agents that say, ‚ÄúThis idea doesn‚Äôt align with your goals‚Äîpause?‚Äù
  • Architectures that encode ontological repair, not just data pipelining

Most ‚Äúethical AI‚Äù efforts stop at conversation.
I believe we must go further‚Äîinto confrontation, capacity, and care.

Not just better intentions, but better ops.
Not just slower collapse, but tools that can resist empire.

Because the world we are inheriting is not neutral.
It is tilted toward noise, dislocation, and erasure.

And I, for one, do not consent.

These are the wars I fight:

  • A war against institutionalized amnesia
  • A war for systems that serve communities‚Äînot empire
  • A war to restore truth‚Äînot as fact alone, but as navigable coherence

This is what I stand for. This is what I build. This is the future I seek allies for.

With conviction and clarity,
Stephen Wooten II
AI Systems Strategist ‚Ä¢ Civic Technologist ‚Ä¢ Builder of Meaning

[1] The term "Zeitgeist" refers to the defining spirit or mood of a particular period. We call this the "Second Zeitgeist" to signal a transition from the first digital age dominated by extraction and centralization to a new era of regenerative technology.

[2] This document was inspired by numerous previous efforts including the Maintenance Manifesto, the Solar Protocol, and various digital rights frameworks.

This letter is a living document. See our changelog for a history of how our understanding has evolved.
